The  Project  is  a  follow-up  to  the  first  Secondary  Education 
Development  Project  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and 
aims  to  improve  the  quality  of  secondary  education  in  Nepal.  The 
Project  will  (i)  improve  the  learning  environment  by  upgrading  the 
physical  infrastructure  in  schools;  and  (ii)  enhancing  teacher 
capabilities  through  training  of  trainers  and  teachers,  improved 
curriculum, and instruction materials. 
 
The  Project  will  have  four  components:  (i)  increasing  equitable 
access 
for 
educationally disadvantaged groups, ethnic minorities, and girls; (ii) 
an  improved  and  relevant  curriculum,  improved  assessment  and 
accessible instructional materials; (iii) an improved and sustainable 
system  for  the  education,  development  and  management  of 
teachers; and (iv) improved institutional capacity and management 
for more efficient and effective delivery of education.  
 
Limited  access  and  low  quality  of  education  are  key  impediments 
to  economic  and  social  development  of  the  country.  Inequitable 
access  also  contributes  to  social  tensions.  The  Government 
recognizes  education  as  a  key  intervention  for  poverty  reduction. 
Improved  access  to  and  quality  of  secondary  education  will  help 
consolidate the gains from expansion of basic education, produce 
a  skilled  work  force  better  able  to  contribute  to  the  country’s 
economic  development  and  play  a  useful  and  progressive  role  in 
society.  
 
The Project’s objective is to improve the quality of public secondary 
education  and  improve  access  to  education  for  the  underserved 
groups, particularly girls and children from disadvantaged groups.  
 
The  estimated  project  cost  is  $74.8  million  equivalent  of  which 
$9.29 million (12%) is the foreign exchange cost and $65.5 million 
equivalent (88%) the local currency cost.

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

the  most  disadvantaged.  Participation  rates 

Considerable progress in secondary education has been made in the past two decades. 
2. 
Enrollments  in  secondary  education  increased  dramatically  by  324%  in  the  lower  secondary 
grades (grades 6−8) and by 124% at the secondary level (grades 9−10). Despite this, improving 
access to and the quality and efficiency of secondary education remains a formidable challenge. 
Although  the  gross  enrollment  ratio  (GER)2  is  57%  at  the  lower  secondary  level,  the  net 
enrollment  ratio  (NER)3  is  only  31%.  At  the  secondary  level,  the  GER  and  NER  are  39%  and 
21%  respectively.  Such  low  levels  of  participation  in  secondary  education  are  a  severe 
constraint to Nepal’s economic development.  
 
3. 
Within this limited access, there are further disparities by geographic location, as well as 
economic  and  social  background.  Girls  are  disproportionately  disadvantaged  in  all  categories. 
Girls constitute 43% of total primary enrollment, 41% of lower secondary enrollment, and 40% of 
secondary  enrollment.  Significant  gaps  exist  between  the  poor  and  the  nonpoor.  According  to 
the Nepal Living Standards Survey (1996), children from the highest income quartile are twice 
as  likely  to  be  enrolled  in  primary  schools  and  10  times  as  likely  to  be  enrolled  in  secondary 
schools than children from the lowest income quartile. Participation rates also vary considerably 
across the geographic regions with people living in the mountainous belt and the Far Western 
Region  being 
to 
disadvantaged groups also decline as students move to higher levels of education. This is also 
true of students with physical disabilities. Lack of education limits employment opportunities for 
the  poor,  constrains  productivity,  and  perpetuates  poverty.  Lack  of  access  to  education  is  a 
major cause of poverty among Nepal’s disadvantaged groups and contributes to social tensions 
in the country.  
 
4. 
The  overall  quality  and  efficiency  of  secondary  education  is  low.  Schools  have  poor 
physical  infrastructure  and  inadequate  learning  materials,  laboratories,  and  libraries.  Teachers 
are  poorly  qualified,  partially  trained  or  not  trained  at  all,  and  unmotivated.  Limited  resources 
hamper  the  Government’s  ability  to  effect  any  improvements.  Teacher  salaries  account  for 
approximately  95%  of  the  Government’s  expenditure  on  secondary  education.  Of  those  that 
enroll in school, less than 29% reach grade 10. In 2000, the average repetition rate was 13% at 
the  lower  secondary  level  and  9%  at  grade  9.  In  2001,  the  pass  rate  for  the  school  leaving 
certificate (SLC) examination at the end of grade 10 was only 32%. The poor quality of public 
education  has  led  to  a  proliferation  of  private  schools  that  are  accessed  by  the  economically 
advantaged sections of society creating another layer of disparity and disadvantage. The poor 
performance  of  the  education  system  wastes  already  scarce  resources.  The  SESP  seeks  to 
improve  the  efficiency  and  quality  of  education  to  make  it  a  more  effective  tool  of  national 
development (Appendix 1).

B. 

 Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Access 

Analyses  of  the  performance  of  the  education  system  and  identification  of  problems 
5. 
reflect  an  education  system  facing  many  challenges  (Appendix  2).  Challenges  identified  in 
various official documents of the Ministry of Education and Sports (MOES) and agencies active 
in the education sector include (i) low levels of literacy and educational attainment; (ii) unequal 
participation  in  schooling  across  income  and  social  groups,  and  geographic  regions;  (iii)  high 
repetition  and  dropout  rates;  and  (iv)  low  pass  rates  at  the  SLC  level.  A  summary  of  key 
problems (Appendix 3) in education follows.  
 
 
 
6. 
Unequal  Access.  There  are  distinct  disparities  in  physical  infrastructure,  teaching 
resources,  and  learning  materials  for  schools  across  and  within  regions.  The  remote  hill  and 
mountainous  areas  suffer  due  to  poor  accessibility;  but  within  regions,  the  rural  and  remote 
areas  suffer  similar  disadvantages.  These  areas  are  home  to  larger  proportions  of  poorer 
sections of the population. Typically these are also areas of educational disadvantage with low 
participation rates from among economically and socially disadvantaged children including girls. 
A further divide in access to quality education occurs through the provision of private education, 
that not only caters to those who can afford to pay but is concentrated in the more accessible 
regions of the country.  
 
Learning  Environment.  Poor  and  inadequate  physical  facilities  in  schools,  particularly 
7. 
in  rural  and  underdeveloped  areas  have  contributed  to  low  achievement  levels.  Most  schools, 
particularly  in  rural  areas,  were  established  as  primary  schools.  In  response  to  local  demand, 
they  evolved  into  lower  secondary  and  secondary  schools.  Due  to  resource  constraints,  the 
development of physical infrastructure did not match the expansion. Most school buildings are in 
poor  condition,  lack  sanitation  and  piped  water  facilities,  and  have  inadequate  laboratory  and 
library space. Consequently, school infrastructure is a key concern for government.  
 
 
 
8. 
Curriculum  and  Assessment.  Poor  linkages  between  revisions  in  curriculum  and 
classroom teaching and assessment render the revisions ineffective and also severely constrain 
the quality of education. Besides, curriculum, supporting learning materials and approaches to 
assessment need to be revised and updated to meet the needs of a modernizing economy. At 
present, these are reviewed over 5-year and 10-year cycles.  Within these cycles, new curricula 
and  textbooks  have  been  developed  for  lower  secondary,  secondary,  and  higher  secondary 
levels.  New  approaches  to  assessment  have  been  introduced.  However,  the  national 
dissemination  strategies  have  lacked  consistency.  Head  teachers,  teachers,  and  school 
supervisors have been oriented in a cascade of workshops, in some cases supported by self-
learning  handbooks.  Apart  from  grades  9−10,  where  teachers  from  across  the  nation  were 
involved,  participation  by  subject  teachers  has  been  limited.  Little  linkage  exists  between  the 
teacher approaches required by the curriculum and textbooks, and what teachers have learned 
in  preservice  education  courses.  This  has  had  a  negative  impact  on  the  effectiveness  of 
revisions in curriculum.  
 
9. 
Teacher Quality. The low quality of teaching is another major reason for the poor quality 
of  education.  Low  entry-level  qualifications,  inadequate  or  no  training,  poor  motivation,  and 
inadequate  support  and  supervision  contribute  to  the  malaise  of  poor  teaching  quality.  Of  the 
approximately  24,700  teachers  at  the  lower  secondary  level,  about  9,700  are  completely 
untrained  and  3,000  are  partially  trained.  At  the  secondary  level,  of  the  approximately  19,200 
teachers, an estimated 4,850 are untrained and 1,350 are partially trained. Not surprisingly, the 
pass  rate  for  the  SLC  administered  at  the  end  of  grade  10  was  a  dismal  32%  in  2001.  Since

10. 
At the lower secondary level, only 12% teachers are female. At the secondary level, the 
figure  is  even  more  dismal  at  7.6%.  Approximately  45%  of  these  are  concentrated  in  the 
Kathmandu  valley.  A  sample  of  teachers  from  four  districts  classified  as  containing  a  high

The  gross  underrepresentation  of  these  groups  is  a  reflection  of  the  inequities  all  through  the 
education system.  
 
 
 
11.  Management and Institutional Capacity. The administrative setup for the planning and 
management of education has been inadequate and also subject to some experimentation over 
the years. MOES has been overstretched in its administrative, planning, and policy formulation 
functions. This was partly addressed during the design of the second Basic Primary Education 
Program (BPEPII) when the Department of Education (DOE) was created at the national level to 
administer school education, leaving MOES with responsibility for policy and planning. However, 
DOE has been preoccupied with the administration and management of the expanded needs of 
primary education. Lower secondary and secondary education have not received proportionate 
attention.  Institutions  and  agencies  providing  support  to  school  education  have  also  remained 
fragmented by subsector and their capacity for providing quality support has been hampered by 
inadequate  staff  development,  poor  facilities,  and  frequent  movement  of  staff.  These 
weaknesses have resulted in a lack of ownership, weak implementation of policies, inadequate 
capacity for meeting the demands for management, and teacher training. This in turn has had a 
serious negative impact on the overall quality of education.  

 

12. 
Government Policies. Poverty reduction is the Government’s primary development goal 
as enunciated in the 10th Five-Year Plan, which is currently being formulated.  Improving access 
to and the quality and efficiency of education, with particular emphasis on literacy and women’s 
education, is a key component of the Government’s poverty reduction strategy. The draft Policy 
Objectives  for  Education  in  the  10th  Plan  address  poverty  reduction  through  several  policy 
objectives that acknowledge the multidimensional nature of poverty. These include (i) increasing 
community  participation  and  mobilization  in  managing  and  resourcing  school  education,  (ii) 
decentralizing education management and monitoring, (iii) introducing cost sharing in secondary 
education  to  partially  address  issue  of  resource  scarcity,  (iv)  strengthening  institutional  and 
school  management  including  regulation  of  private  schools,  (v)  providing  school-based 
management for greater ownership, (vi) providing institutional capacity building, (vii) increasing 
the use of information communication technology (ICT) in education, (viii) improving access to 
education  for  girls  and  other  disadvantaged  children,  (ix)  increasing  partnerships  with  civil 
society and the private sector, and (x) improving monitoring and evaluation. 
 
13. 
Although  government  policies  are  becoming  more  coherent  and  educational  goals  are 
being  defined  under  a  broad  policy  umbrella,  policy  reform  is  hampered  by  the  complexity  of 
existing  policy  structures;  limited  financial,  institutional,  and  professional  capacity  to  carry  out 
reform;  and  to  some  degree,  a  systemic,  institutional,  and  stakeholder  resistance  to  major 
change. In the past, policy limitations have had a serious impact on the quality and efficiency of 
education. While some limitations are recognized, key policy initiatives necessary for making the 
education system more efficient have been discussed in detail, agreed upon, and are addressed 
by the Project. 
 
14. 
ADB’s  Sector  Strategy.  In  its  draft  education  policy,  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) articulates its vision for education, as  “all children and adults will have equitable access 
to education of sufficient quality to empower them to break the poverty cycle, to improve their 
quality  of  life,  and  to  participate  effectively  in  national  development.”    ADB’s  poverty  reduction 

 4 

strategy  also  calls  for  support  for  provision  of  basic  services,  including  education,  as  a  key 
poverty  reduction  measure.  The  Project  supports  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  update 
for  Nepal,  which  emphasizes  support  for  the  Government’s  educational  reforms  and 
decentralization policies. 
 
ADB’s  strategy4  for  the  education  sector  in  Nepal  has  evolved  to  emphasize 
15. 
strengthening  investments  made  during  past  projects  and  to  build  upon  them  to  move  toward 
holistic planning and management for the education sector. Thus, the process begun under the 
ADB-financed Primary Education Development Project for creating an infrastructure for teacher 
training  was  supported  under  the  Teacher  Education  Project5  and  will  be  strengthened  and 
consolidated  under  the  proposed  SESP.  In  other  areas  such  as  curriculum  and  examination 
reform,  school  management,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation,  the  SESP  will  build  upon 
investments  made  under  the  Secondary  Education  Development  Project  (SEDP),  and  at  the 
same  time,  move  these  areas  toward  greater  cohesion  and  complementarity.  The  SESP  has 
been  designed  to  support  ADB’s  strategy  of  taking  a  longer  term  perspective  of  sector 
development  and  committing  to  a  series  of  interventions  that  focus  on  high  priority  goals  and 
measurable targets within a sector policy framework. ADB assistance to the education sector in 
Nepal is also consistent with the Government’s priorities of improving access to and quality of 
education. The SESP supports the Millennium Development Goals of promoting gender parity in 
secondary  education,  poverty  eradication,  and  improved  child  and  maternal  health  through  a 
better-educated population.  
 
External  Assistance.  External  assistance  to  education  has  been  increasing  over  the 
16. 
years. The proportion of external assistance in the total education budget increased from 7% in

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Project Benefits and Impacts 

71. 
Continued  economic  growth  requires  a  well-educated  population  and  workforce. 
Investment  in  lower  secondary  and  secondary  education,  where  basic  cognitive  skills  are 
acquired  and  consolidated,  is  particularly  valuable  because  it  improves  productivity  and 
increases  basic  welfare.  Investment  in  secondary  education  also  improves  the  quality  of,  and 
increases the number of entrants to, higher levels of education, where higher cognitive skills are 
acquired,  with  the  resulting  improvement  of  higher  order  productivity.  Investment  in  lower 
secondary  and  secondary  education  also  increases  the  benefits  of  other  social  services  (e.g., 
educated  women  benefit  more  from  health  services).  In  addition,  society  places  an  intrinsic 
value  on  education,  especially  on  basic  and  secondary  education.  The  implication  is  that 
investment in this subsector has potentially high returns, both for the individual and for society.  
 
72. 
In  Nepal,  at  present,  the  quality  of  educational  achievement  is  relatively  poor,  and 
investments in improving it can be expected to have significant positive returns. In the long term, 
the  project  outcomes  are  expected  to  be  (i)  human  development  and  productivity  efficiency 
through greater professional qualification of teaching and managerial staff, increased numbers 
of  higher  quality  secondary  students,  and  a  workforce  prepared  for  local  production  and 
commercial  markets;  (ii)  social  benefits  derived  from  girls'  education  such  as  lower  fertility, 
increased  prenatal  care  utilization,  improved  health  and  nutrition  status  of  their  families,  and 
higher educational attainment of their children; and (iii) greater redistribution gains as a result of 
its focus on low income and underserved students.  
 
73. 
The economic benefits of the SESP will be two-fold. First, substantial economic benefits 
are  expected  to  accrue  from  efficiency  gains.  The  cost  of  each  student  repeated  year  is  $29. 
The SESP will lead to a reduction in repetition rates at the lower secondary and secondary by 
12% and 7% respectively by the end of the project period. Students who do not drop out in a 
given year increase their future wage-earning potential. Studies indicate that each extra year of 
schooling  increases  labor  productivity  and  income  earned.  Improved  quality  of  secondary 
education  will  attract  more  primary  education  completers  to  continue  their  studies,  thus 
increasing their wage potential. The scholarships provided under the SESP will lead to attracting 
girls  and  students  from  other  disadvantaged  groups  to  continue  their  education  at  the  lower 
secondary and secondary level. This will have a positive impact on their labor productivity and 
income levels of their families helping them break out of the cycle of poverty (Appendix 11). 
 
74. 
Education is a key means for assisting the poor break the cycle of poverty. The SESP 
has a pro-poor focus.  About 43% of the total project cost will be provided to improve equitable 
access by rehabilitating schools and providing scholarships for girls and disadvantaged children. 
New classrooms will be constructed for students in rural, underserved areas where most of the 
students are poor. The SESP’s scholarship program for girls is targeted at rural schools in the 
most disadvantaged areas. The educational benefits of the SESP will derive from the improved 
quality  of  education  and  from  the  improved  efficiency  of  education  services.  The  SESP  is 
expected  to  have  substantial  qualitative  benefits,  deriving  from  the  introduction  of  the  new 
curriculum,  the  development  of  improved  textbooks  and  other  materials,  improved  training  of 
teachers,  and  licensing  of  teachers.  This  focus  on  quality  improvement  will  in  the  long  run 
contribute  to  reduced  inequities  among  beneficiaries.  The  SESP  is  expected  to  result  in 
significant gains in internal efficiency, by reducing repetition and helping to induce students not 
to drop out. Improved quality, including improved internal efficiency, will also reduce the cost of 

 17 

secondary  education,  thereby  freeing  up  resources  to  encourage  school  enrolment  and 
attendance among the poor. 
 
75. 
The  direct  beneficiaries  of  the  Project’s  equity,  access,  and  qualitative  improvement 
programs  will  be  the  approximately  1.3  million  current  secondary  students,  and  their 
successors.  Secondary  beneficiaries  will  include  the  approximately  3,100  teacher  trainers; 
4,500  head  teachers;  12,500  teachers;  150,000  SMC,  district  development  committee,  VDC, 
and  VEC  members;  200  resource  center  managers;  and  2,700  supervisors,  planners,  and 
education  administrators  who  will  be  the  focus  of  staff  development  programs.    About  125 
female  teachers  will  be  provided  with  accommodation  facilities  in  the  remote  and  rural  areas. 
Secondary education support agencies including SEDEC, CDC, NFEC, OCE, DEC, DOE, and 
NCED,  will  benefit  from  capacity  building  programs.  Project  support  for  scholarships  for  girls 
and students from disadvantaged groups will be weighted directly to poorer regions (Appendix 
12). 
 
76. 
The quality of students’ education will be enhanced; the reduced repetition and dropout 
rates  imply  that  individuals  will  attain  higher  levels  of  educational  achievement.  The  net  result 
will be a greater return to the students from their investment in education. Increased access will 
expand  the  coverage  of  education,  with  greater  enrolments,  further  increasing  the  number  of 
beneficiaries.  Secondary education graduates of improved quality will also contribute to human 
development and improved status of women by increasing the number of students qualified for 
higher  education,  improving  living  standards  and  health,  reducing  population  growth,  and 
providing people with the means to engage in productive employment.

The SESP’s civil works enhancements are focused in poor areas selected on the basis 
of  educational  and  economic  disadvantage,  and  therefore,  will  have  a  positive  impact  on

are certain risks that are not project-specific but could affect project performance.  

 
82. 
Security  Situation.  The  major  risk  arises  from  the  broader  context  of  the  security 
situation.  The  Project  aims  to  target  the  poorer  districts  for  intensive  inputs  for  improving  the 
learning  environment.  Recently  many  poor  and  remote  districts  have  been  affected  by 
insurgency. The selection of districts will be done after due assessment of the security situation. 
However,  the  security  situation  may  remain  volatile.  The  implications  of  either  a  failure  to 
commence  in  selected  districts,  or  the  need  to  pull  out  before  interventions  have  been 
completed will need to be assessed. The Project has built in the flexibility to assess the security 
situation  before  making  geographically  targeted  interventions.  However,  since  poor  quality  of 
education in public schools is an important plank of the insurgency agenda, a program that aims 
to improve the quality of public schools with the active participation of the community and with 
visible positive impact may not encounter resistance.   
 
83. 
Sustainability.  The  Project  will  generate  continuing  additional  incremental  cost  of 
approximately $0.5 million annually after the project period. This incremental cost will accrue on 
account of operation and maintenance of facilities and equipment, and salary costs for positions 
created  for  institutional  consolidation  and  strengthening.  These  costs  will  be  in  continuation  of 
recurrent  costs  the  Government  will  support  during  project  implementation.  The  Government 
has  committed  to  continuing  budgetary  provision  for  the  recurrent  costs.  Despite  the  severe 
resource  constraints,  budgetary  support  to  education  is  being  maintained.  A  combination  of 
increased  resources  for  security  and  a  decline  in  revenues  could  have  a  negative  impact  on 
resource allocations for education, as well as on the timely availability of counterpart funds. This 
may  necessitate  a  review  of  project  design  and  changes  where  necessary  without  a  major 
impact  on  broad  project  objectives.  However,  some  project  gains,  particularly  those  that 
strengthen  capacity;  improve  the  curriculum,  classroom  assessment,  and  examination;  and 
improve teacher competencies, will have long-term beneficial impact and are not susceptible to 
short-term resource constraints.  
 
84. 
Continuity  of  Pesonnel.  Frequent  changes  of  senior  civil  servants  could  affect  the 
overall direction and continuity of the Project. Of late, trends in continuity of personnel both at 
the  ministry  level  and  related  agencies  have  been  positive.  Success  of  the  capacity  building 
inputs  will,  however,  depend  upon  institutional  leadership  and  continuity  of  personnel.  The 
Project will continue to emphasize this aspect with Government from time to time.

SECONDARY EDUCATION AND THE EDUCATION SECTOR 

 
1. 
Despite  the  substantial  increases  in  enrolments,  the  overall  quality  of  secondary 
education in Nepal remains poor. The key issues that impact quality of secondary education are 
as follows: 

 
The School Curriculum 

Examinations 

A. 
 
2. 
The curriculum has been criticized for an academic emphases; no provision for local and 
regional  flexibility;  domination  by  the  school  leaving  certificate  (SLC)  examination;  and  as  a 
consequence  the  students  have  to  resort  to  rote  learning;  few  opportunities  for  practical 
activities and not related to the labor market. 
 
Curriculum  reform  was  a  major  focal  point  of  the  Secondary  Education  Development 
3. 
Project  (SEDP).  The  overall  structure  of  the  curriculum  was  left  untouched  by  SEDP,  as  the 
project focused exclusively on revising the curriculum of existing subjects. Evaluations suggest 
that  the  SEDP  was  highly  influential  in  developing  and  implementing  a  less  overloaded,  more 
student centered, and more activity-oriented curriculum for grades 9 and 10. The textbooks for 
these  grades  are  of  a  higher  technical  and  educational  quality  than  those  for  the  previous 
curriculum.  This  points  to  the  need  to  undertake  a  fairly  comprehensive  revision  of  the  lower 
secondary curriculum. 
 
4. 
The  role  of  vocational  education  at  the  school  level  has  been  extensively  debated  and 
there  is  consensus  that  the  technological  advancement  and  globalization  of  the  economy 
demands that education be life-skill oriented to enable students to make a meaningful economic 
contribution.  Community  and  political  support  for  a  more  relevant  job-orientated  curriculum  is 
strong. Demand for computer education in public school is growing.  
 
B. 
 
5. 
Classroom assessment of student learning is embryonic in Nepal. There is a district level 
examination  at  the  end  of  lower  secondary  school  (grade  8).  Much  more  important  than  the 
grade 8 examination, is the SLC at grade 10. This examination, with its heavy emphasis on rote 
learning,  has  considerable  negative  influence  on  the  teaching-learning  processes.  An 
examination  pass  is  connected  to  future  public  and  private  career  possibilities  and  to  social 
prestige. 
 
The SEDP evaluation report suggests that the capacity to ensure increased validity and 
6. 
reliability  in  assessment  has  increased  in  the  Office  of  the  Controller  of  Examination  (OCE), 
although not sufficiently. Pass rates at the SLC have been improving over the last decade and 
in 1999 close to 50% of the regular candidates passed. However pass rates vary considerably 
every  year,  as  the  criterion  in  each  subject  is  to  obtain  32%  of  the  marks  and  it  has  proved 
difficult to ensure that examination papers are of the same level of difficulty every year. The first 
SLC  examination  according  to  the  new  curriculum  took  place  in  2001,  and  created  further 
problems.  First,  it  took  about  one  more  month  to  publish  the  results;  second  the  pass  rate 
dropped to 31.6%; and third, there was dissatisfaction with the parallel sets of questions, due to 
striking  differences  in  the  level  of  difficulty.  It  follows  that  more  work  needs  to  be  done  on  the 
SLC.

Preservice training is the responsibility of the Faculty of Education (FOE). FOE is often 
criticized  for  its  low  academic  standard,  so  much  so  that  even  if  trained  candidates  are 
available, schools are reported to prefer teachers who have earned their degrees in other fields 
than  in  education.  There  are  two  main  reasons  for  this.  First,  some  of  the  campuses  are  very 
small  and  have  few  physical  and  human  resources  to  provide  high-quality  teacher  education. 
Second,  the  FOE  courses  are  not  primarily  teacher  education  courses,  but  rather  academic 
courses in education that focus only to a limited extent on the professional competencies of the 
prospective teachers, in spite of the fact that about 50% of the graduates go into teaching. The 
FOE-courses do not reflect the emphases of the secondary school curriculum. 
 
10. 
In-service training courses take place at the 25 secondary education development units 
(SEDUs). Presently the SEDUs train about 5,000 teachers a year. In general they provide 6−7 
months of training a year. The number of trainees in SEDUs has fallen over the past 4 years, a 
development  which  may  reflect  the  difficult  financial  situation  of  the  SEDUs.  The  SEDUs  are 
strongly  dependent  on  development  assistance  and  cannot  become  financially  sustainable 
without such input in the foreseeable future. 
 
The  problems  faced  by  the  SEDUs  include  (i)  small  size,  inadequately  equipped,  and 
11. 
limited resources for maintenance and replacement of materials; (ii) understaffed, with only two 
permanent  posts  of  the  chief  and  an  assistant;  (iii)  reliance  on  external  trainers  who  are 
secondary  teachers  from  nearby  schools;  (iv)  trainers  and  trainees  are  selected  often  for 
political reasons, which leads to a lack of commitment; and (vi) the training is not sufficient for 
the teachers to become formally trained and there is little incentive for them to participate. 
 
D. 
 
12. 
The educational management structure is the result of government efforts over the past 
five decades to establish a sound management system for the national education system. The 
principal  tasks  of  the  Ministry  of  Education  and  Sports  (MOES)  are  planning,  policymaking, 
monitoring,  and  evaluation.  Currently  too  many  institutions  report  directly  to  MOES  and  this 
results in too little time being spent on policymaking and planning tasks.  
 
13.

education.    The  five  regional  education  directors  and  75  DEOs  report  directly  to  the  director 
general of DOE.  The present structure of DOE appears to have a visible bias in favor of primary 
education  and  educational  administration.  The  regional  education  directorates  (REDs)  created 
to decentralize school management are shrinking in terms of their responsibilities and authority.

E. 

Summary: Major Issues 

 
16. 
Analyses  of  the  education  system  indicate  that  it  faces  serious  challenges.  Challenges 
identified include low levels of educational attainment, unequal participation in schooling across 
income  and  social  groups,  high  repetition  and  dropout  rates  throughout  the  system,  and  a 
generally low quality of education that does not serve the labor market well.   
 
17. 
Further challenges include a teaching force that is poorly managed, poorly trained, or not 
trained at all, often teaching subjects for which they are not qualified; an overloaded curriculum 
and weak assessment system; weak management and institutional capacity; inadequate public 
resources for education that are inappropriately distributed; and a system of financial allocation 
that encourages neither efficiency nor generation of additional resources. 
 
18. 
Another  issue  of  concern  at  the  secondary  level  is  whether  it  should  include  grades 
6−10, 6−12, or 9−12. The problem of the schooling system is not in the lower grades but at the 
terminal  end  where  more  uniformity  is  necessary.  The  debate  is  one  that  can  only  take  place 
within a sector framework. Access, equity, and relevance are at the core of the debate on the 
future  structure  of  the  sector  that  needs  to  be  addressed  in  a  whole  sector,  rather  than  a 
subsector, perspective.

Economic Benefits of the Project 

1. 
Despite  considerable  progress  made  in  education  in  Nepal  over  the  last  two  decades, 
the gross enrolment ratio (GER) at the lower secondary and secondary school level is 55% and 
35%  respectively.  Girls  constitute  only  41%  with  considerable  variation  in  participation  by 
gender, as well as by social and income group, across the regions and ecological zones. The 
quality  of  education  also  varies  substantially.  Approximately  two  thirds  of  lower  secondary 
teachers  and  one  half  of  secondary  teachers  are  untrained,  and  most  teachers  at  the  higher 
secondary level are only employed on a part-time or temporary basis. 
 
2. 
In  Nepal  as  elsewhere,  correlation  between  educational  development  and  reduction  in 
the incidence of poverty, improvement in labor productivity, economic growth, and the quality of 
life is strong. Relevant curriculum, improved pedagogical skills and teachers’ competencies, and 
strengthened  management  of  secondary  education  will  all  serve  to  enhance  the  quality  of 
education  and  cost-effectiveness  of  public  and  household  spending  on  secondary  schooling. 
With  improved  quality,  parents  will  be  more  inclined  to  send  their  children  to  school,  and 
students  will  be  increasingly  motivated  to  stay  in  school  and  complete  their  secondary  school 
education. Student dropouts and repetitions will decrease, and more students will successfully 
complete grades on a year-to-year basis and finalize their grade 8 and school leaving certificate 
(SLC)  certificates.  In  supporting  the  development  of  a  better-educated  work  force  and 
population,  the  Project  in  turn  supports  the  acceleration  of  Nepal’s  transition  to  a  more 
technologically advanced agriculture and industrial-based economy and the strengthening of its 
economic development.

The recent global recession and the intensification of internal security issues have both 
had  effects  on  Nepal’s  economic  growth  and  impacted  Nepal’s  capacity  to  pursue  it

significantly. Ensuring internal security is considered a priority without which development and

The  strategy  of  the  Government  is  to  “harness  and  channel  limited  resources  within  a 
medium-term  framework  in  order  to  ensure  that  the  major  growth  and  poverty  reduction 
outcomes  envisaged  in  the  Tenth  Plan  [can]  be  achieved.”1  In  support  of  this  strategy,  MOES 
and each of the other five-core line ministries, have prepared sectoral medium-term expenditure 
frameworks (MTEFs), which detail actionable prioritized programs to serve as a bridge between 
annual budgets and the Tenth Plan.

Under  MOES’s  MTEF  the  estimated  2001/02  budget  for  the  SESP  is  $38.1  million,  of

teachers  salaries)  and  $0.7  million  is  for  the  development  budget  (comprised  solely  of  foreign 
grant).  For  the  regular  budget  (recurring  costs)  this  reflects  an  almost  15%  increase  over  the 
revised  budget  for  FY2000/01,  which  in  turn  reflects  an  increase  of  over  40%  over  the  actual 
budget  for  FY1999/2000.  In  contrast,  the  development  budget,  i.e.,  in  terms  of  the 
Government’s  self-generated  resources,  has  fallen  from  $0.1  million  in  FY1999/2000  to  no 
budget  allocation  for  both  FY2000/01  and  2001/02.  For  those  fiscal  years,  the  development 
budget  was  comprised  entirely  of  a  foreign  loan  of  $1.1  million  in  FY1999/2000  and  foreign 
grants of $0.7 million for each of FY2000/01 and FY2001/02.
